title: James Borders
text:
James Borders, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorBoston University





James Borders, PhD, CCC-SLP is a speech pathologist and Postdoctoral Research Fellow in the Upper Airway Dysfunction Lab at Teachers College, Columbia University. His clinical research focuses on the rehabilitation of voice and swallowing dysfunction in neurodegenerative disease. James is also passionate about meta-science, statistics, and how these practices affect the transparency, rigor, and replicability of science.

Visit Dr.¬†Borders‚Äô Website







 Back to top

title: Anne C. Reed
text:
Anne C. Reed, EdS, CCC-SLPDoctoral CandidateFlorida State University





Anne C. Reed is a doctoral candidate in Communication Science and Disorders at Florida State University, as well as a FIREFLIES fellow with a focus on the interdisciplinary study of reading through the Florida Center for Reading Research (FCRR). Anne‚Äôs research interests include using an implementation science framework to study the effectiveness of services provided by SLPs in addressing the challenges faced by students with speech-language and reading difficulties. Drawing from her extensive professional background, Anne brings a wealth of practical insight to her academic and clinical pursuits.

Visit Anne‚Äôs Website







 Back to top

title: Jennifer Markfeld
text:
Jennifer Markfeld, MS, CF-SLPPhD CandidateVanderbilt University





Jennifer is a clinical fellow in speech-language pathologiy and PhD candidate at Vanderbilt University in the Biobehavioral Approaches to NeuroDevelopment Lab. Her broad interests include language development, early language experiences, caregiver-infant interactions, implementation science, and interventions to support infants who are at increased likelihood for neurodevelopmental conditions. Jennifer is passionate about increasing awareness of open science practices and is thrilled to be on the CSDisseminate team!






 Back to top

title: Mariam El Amin
text:
Mariam El Amin, PhDPostdoctoral Research AssociateUniversity of South Carolina





Mariam is interested in understanding how environmental factors such maternal linguistic input and the home literacy environment contribute to language development in monolingual and multilingual speakers with DLD and/or dyslexia.
As a clinician from the global south, Mariam is interested in increasing access, transparency, and diversification of science in communication sciences and disorders (CSD) through open science practices.
Visit the Dr.¬†El Amin‚Äôs Website!







 Back to top

title: Alisa Baron
text:
Alisa Baron, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorUniversity of Rhode Island





Alisa Baron, PhD, CCC-SLP is a multilingual speech language pathologist and Assistant Professor at the University of Rhode Island. Her research focuses on how children process speech and language and how this may differ in monolingual and bilingual children with and without developmental disorders (developmental language disorder (DLD), autism spectrum disorders (ASD), and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)). Alisa uses behavioral measures, along with eye tracking, electroencephalography (EEG), and functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) technologies to identify differences that may not be detectable behaviorally.
Alisa is eager to support academics at any stage of their journey in learning and implementing open science practices.





 Back to top

title: Micah Hirsch
text:
Micah Hirsch, PhDPostdoctoral Research AssociateBoston University





Micah‚Äôs research interests are in motor speech disorders, speech science, and metascience. Specifically, their interests are focused on better understanding the various perceptual and acoustic factors that impact speech perception and production for people with dysarthria. Their research interest also aims to increase the methodological rigor of measuring these factors in dysarthria research.
Micah believes that open science practices help increase the rigor of research in CSD by making the process and findings from more accessible, reproducible, and transparent.
Visit the Dr.¬†Hirsch‚Äôs Website!







 Back to top

title: Children‚Äôs Literacy and Speech Sound (CLaSS) Lab
text:
PI: Kelly Farquharson, PhD, CCC-SLP
The Children‚Äôs Literacy and Speech Sound (CLaSS) Lab has a mission to help children with speech and language impairments achieve classroom success. We work towards this goal in two related lines of work. One has examined how working memory, language, and orthography may influence children‚Äôs abilities to learn new words, read, and achieve age-appropriate speech production. A related line of work has examined how speech therapy-level variables, such as SLPs‚Äô stress, job satisfaction, therapy quality, and IEP goals, may impact the outcomes seen in children with speech and language impairments.


Visit the Lab Website!







Kelly Farquharson, PhD, CCC-SLP








Receiving the OSSPEAC Award, a Clinical Achievement award, from Dr.¬†Wayne Secord








Poster presentation with Katie Goodwin (lab undergrad) and Dr.¬†Whitney Schneider-Cline, collaborator

title: CSDisseminate
text:
CSDisseminate


Disseminating knowledge and resources about open science practices to researchers and clinicians in the field of Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD).

title: CSDisseminate
text:
Learn about‚Ä¶

‚òÇÔ∏è Open Science
Open science is an umbrella term for a set of practices aimed at making scientific research, data, and dissemination accessible to all.





‚úÖ Preregistration
Preregistration is the practice of documenting and publicly sharing the research plan and hypotheses before conducting a study to increase transparency and reduce bias.


üìê Open Methods
Open methods involve the transparent sharing of research methodologies, protocols, and processes, allowing others to replicate, verify, and build upon the original research.


üíΩ Open Data
Open data refers to data that is freely available for anyone to use, modify, and share without restrictions, promoting transparency, innovation, and collaboration.


üîì Open Access & Self-Archiving
Open access is the practice of providing unrestricted online access to scholarly research, allowing anyone to read, download, and share it freely.


üçé Open Educational Resources
Open educational resources are freely accessible, openly licensed materials used for teaching and learning, allowing users to legally use, modify, and distribute them.

text:
Join us as we expand our reach to all CSD scientists!

title: Join Us
text:
Join us as we expand our reach to all CSD scientists!
Check out the options listed below that best match your interests. Then, send us an email at CSDisseminate@gmail.com or use the contact form below to let us know how you‚Äôd like to participate!

title: Join Us
text:
Ambassadors
Want to help your colleagues get started with open science practices, beginning with self-archiving?
Become a CSDisseminate Ambassador at your institution or within your professional network.
CSDisseminate was founded with a focus on self-archiving, helping researchers share their work freely and legally to increase access for clinicians, scientists, and the public. While self-archiving remains an important goal, we plan to expand our efforts to include additional open science practices such as data sharing and other forms of transparent research dissemination.
As an Ambassador, you will serve as a local resource, supporting your colleagues as they take meaningful steps toward making their research more accessible. To get started:

Watching the Self-Archiving 101 workshop video (or attending a live Self-Archiving 101 workshop).
Taking the self-assessment to see if there are any concepts you want to brush up on.

Then:

Starting to self-archive your own or your lab‚Äôs research.

Earn a place as a featured scientist who self-archives on our site!
Earn badges for self-archiving (coming soon)!

Presenting a Self-Archiving 101 workshop at your institution.

Customize these slides & resources with information about your institution.
Present anywhere you like! During a seminar, course, lab meeting, or department meeting.

Being available to answer questions from your colleagues about the steps of self-archiving.

Use our Forum (coming soon) to crowdsource answers to difficult or complicated questions.

Sharing social media posts from CSDisseminate to relevant social media groups or platforms.


Does my Institution need a CSDisseminate Ambassador? ‚Äã
Here are some ideas to help you better understand if/how self-archiving is currently being done at your institution or within your organization:
Review your institution‚Äôs lab web pages & see if/how they list their publications.

Are articles recently updated with a full citation?
Are articles linked to the doi?
Are self-archived, free versions of manuscripts linked?
Are they following appropriate guidelines re: which version is allowed to be posted?

Find out if your institution has a repository for articles. Talk to your institution‚Äôs library/research dept to get a handle on how the institutional repository works.

Who do you contact if you have an article to submit to the repository?
What versions of articles will they accept?
How quickly are articles posted after submitting to the repository?
Are you able to revise versions of articles submitted to the repository?

At most Universities, there‚Äôs quite a bit of variability in how much each lab or scientist participates in self-archiving. But having a point-person to discuss it with is helpful for pretty much everyone!
Thank you for considering being a self-archiving Ambassador. If interested, please contact csdisseminate@gmail.com.

title: Join Us
text:
Collaborators
Are you a self-archiver who is interested in supporting the mission of CSDisseminate in more of a long-term role?
‚ÄãCSDisseminate collaborators actively participate in quarterly meetings.
Collaborators are expected to:

Provide input on direction and mission of CSDisseminate
Seek out new content to share with scientists and clinicians
Regularly/Semi-regularly participate and/or lead activities or events hosted by CSDisseminate
Support content development for CSDisseminate events, CSDisseminate website, social media
Be an Ambassador for self-archiving at your institution or within your organization.

title: OpenCSD and CSDissemiante join forces!
text:
Hello, world!
We‚Äôve got some exciting news: OpenCSD and CSDisseminate are joining forces and becoming one working group! Our mission is still the same: to spread the word about open science in communication sciences and disorders (CSD). But now we‚Äôre doing it together.

Why the merge?
CSDisseminate started during the pandemic as a way to raise awareness about self-archiving. Over time, we felt proud of that work but also wanted to branch out and talk about other open science practices like sharing open data, preregistration, registered reports, open educational resources, and more. That‚Äôs what led to the creation of OpenCSD.
But, the truth is we‚Äôre all volunteers, doing this work as a side passion project. And in the past few years, life has been busy. Many of us have gone through big transitions‚Äîfinishing PhDs, starting postdocs or faculty roles, having babies‚Äîand we realized that trying to run two separate projects just didn‚Äôt make sense anymore.
We‚Äôre more effective (and have more fun) when we work together.


So what‚Äôs new?
We‚Äôre merging under the name CSDisseminate, with a fresh coat of purple paint and a renewed commitment to making open science more accessible in our field. We‚Äôll be tackling a broader range of topics moving forward‚Äîand first up is one we‚Äôre especially excited about: sharing open data.
Stay tuned!




 Back to top

title: Audibility, Perception, and Cognition Lab
text:
PI: Ryan McCreery, PhD
Ryan McCreery, PhD, is the Director of Research and Audiology at Boys Town National Research Hospital. He is a hearing scientist dedicated to improving the developmental outcomes of children who are hard of hearing. He directs the Audibility, Perception, and Cognition laboratory, where we explore how children‚Äôs auditory, linguistic, and cognitive skills impact their ability to understand speech in complex listening environments. His current research projects focus on developing ways to improve the ways we test children‚Äôs hearing, and fit hearing aids for children who are hard of hearing.


Visit the Lab Website!







Ryan McCreery, PhD, Director of Research and Audiology, standing outside of Boys Town National Research Hospital. Fun fact‚ÄîRyan completed his audiology clinical externship at Boys Town!








Brenda Ryals, Editor-in-Chief of Ear & Hearing, presenting a special recognition to Mary Pat Moeller, Ryan McCreery, Ruth Bentler, Pat Stelmachowicz, Beth Walker, and Merry Spratford on behalf of the Outcomes of Children with Hearing Loss team for their work on a supplement edition of Ear & Hearing. Go to link








Members of the Audibility, Perception, and Cognition laboratory holding a virtual lab meeting. In addition to meeting online, our lab has created virtual testing protocols to move experiments online, expanding our ability to visit with children and families all over the US!







 Back to top

title: Helen Long
text:
Helen Long, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorCase Western Reserve University





Dr.¬†Helen Long‚Äôs programmatic research examines early communication development in children with cerebral palsy to advance early identification and intervention of speech, language and communication impairments in this population.
Dr.¬†Long is an advocate of free and public access to scientific manuscripts for clinicians and scientists, and is dedicated to advancing knowledge on how to share and access research.
Visit the Dr.¬†Long‚Äôs Website!







 Back to top

title: Brittany Ciullo
text:
Brittany Ciullo, MA, CCC-SLPPhD StudentUMass Amherst





Brittany Ciullo is a PhD student in the Department of Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. She is interested in all things language and literacy. Brittany‚Äôs current research focuses on the implementation of participation-based approaches with children with communication disorders in schools. A former school-based speech-language pathologist, she is passionate about increasing accessibility and transparency in all parts of the research process to maximize clinical outcomes.






 Back to top

title: Danika Pfeiffer
text:
Danika Pfeiffer, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorOld Dominion University





Danika‚Äôs primary research interest is in enhancing young children‚Äôs early language and literacy skills through collaborative school-based partnerships. This includes providing educators with interprofessional training at the preservice and in-service levels.
Danika is passionate about improving accessibility of research and using open science as a means to promote collaborations that enhance the research process.
Visit the Dr.¬†Pfeiffer‚Äôs Website







 Back to top

title: Austin Thompson
text:
Austin Thompson, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorUniversity of Houston





Austin Thompson, Ph.D., CCC-SLP, is a speech-language pathologist and assistant professor in the Communication Sciences and Disorders department at the University of Houston. His research investigates the perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic speech characteristics of individuals with dysarthria secondary to progressive neurogenic disorders (e.g., Parkinson‚Äôs disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis).
Austin is passionate about supporting researchers to embrace open-science practices to improve their work‚Äôs scientific rigor, reproducibility, and accessibility.
Visit the SPEAK Lab Website







 Back to top

title: Jessica Salley Riccardi
text:
Jessica Salley Riccardi, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorUniversity of Maine





Dr.¬†Riccardi is interested in long-term outcomes after childhood brain injury, particularly in the area of cognitive-communication and in high-risk groups.
Dr.¬†Riccardi is passionate about getting research in clinicians‚Äô hands to change practice and improve outcomes for our clients.
Visit the BEaR Lab Website







 Back to top

title: Andrea Ford
text:
Andrea Ford, PhD, CCC-SLPAssistant ProfessorUniversity of Cincinnati





Andrea‚Äôs research seeks to forge genuine partnerships between educators and researchers to drive the use of evidence-based communication strategies that enhance communication skills in young children with language delays and disabilities. Additionally, Andrea is focused on ensuring the reliability of our outcome measurements by applying generalizability theory, aiming to produce robust, consistent data that support intervention effectiveness.
As a former early childhood speech therapist in the schools, Andrea is passionate about making her work‚Äîand that of others‚Äîopenly available and accessible for everyone to use.





 Back to top

title: Collin Brice
text:
Collin Brice, MS, CCC-SLPPhD CandidateUniversity of Cincinnati





Collin (he/him) is a researcher in speech-language pathology with interests in mixed methods, gender perception in voice, and neuroimaging using fNIRS. His work explores how listeners experience individuals‚Äô speech. He is also passionate about pedagogy and advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I) practices in education and research, with a strong commitment to open science and inclusive methodologies.






 Back to top
